body: Rebased to master again.

@markusthoemmes ah OK, I think I understand now.

Can I specify from gradle test command to only compile and run the 3 classes that I need for apigw, and nothing else?
Or I'm force to create a gradle task with some includes like this?

```
task testLeanAPIGW(type: Test) {
    include 'whisk.core.cli.test.ApiGwTests'
    include 'whisk.core.apigw.actions.test.*'
    include 'apigw.healthtests.*'
}
```

By the way this will be temporary, until we move out all apigw related things out (including scala test cases) of the core repo.

@tardieu wrt to tmpfs: In the past I did some performance testing on tmpfs vs. actual disk using various storage drivers. We are currently using overlay to store container filesystems which has a write speed of about 250M/s compared to tmpfs which peaks at about 700M/s so it is about 3 times faster in writing to a (single) disk.

We haven't used tmpfs for user containers yet because RAM is the most expensive resource you can get on a host. Other than that it is a great improvement of course.
@rabbah adopted your suggestion

OK opened a pr to move the content (with and w/o history - i think the history is not very deep/meaningful so not sure it's worth keeping). If we do remove the mobile directory, have to sort out the nginx build which packages the app for download.

As is give us the ability to lower the cold latency on swift, that is seating around the 3 seconds.
Anything else builds on top
Simpler but less powerful...  With this technique you can bring along third party modules that are not already included in the Docker container.
Docs should not preclude the simpler use case which is easier for tire kickers.

I have implemented @starpit solution in: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/compare/master...tardieu:issue-1728-vm

It fixes the current issue. The performance is similar to the original code and the error messages are sensible.

FWIW, using a `vm.runInNewContext` instead of `vm.runInThisContext` is about 30x slower but still 3-4x faster than using a file on my system.
Note that we once used `vm.runInNewContext` and it caused a huge memory leak. Please keep that in mind.
iirc there was some discussion about whether we were really seeing a memory leak or gc overhead - but yeah what @markusthoemmes said... it bit us before.
Given all this information - I'm inclined to accept the original solution as the best compromise.
LGTM

Good work @tardieu on getting to the bottom of this and doing the comparisons.
Based on all the input specially what @domdom82 points about no tmpfs (which what I was thinking).

Let's go with the original proposal with the function wrapper `function () { return message.code }()` or something like that I can't remember the details.

I'm ok with the trade off this give us the ability of using `let` and `const` and isolation of global context, even if it doesn't give us line number for exceptions.

With pr #1977, I'm proposing a patch to fix the CN name.

```
$ OPENWHISK_API_HOST=guest.dockerhost redo setup edge
$ wsk action create hello tests/dat/actions/echo.js -a web-export true
$ curl https://guest.dockerhost/api/v1/experimental/web/guest/default/hello.json --cacert /Users/Shared/nginx/openwhisk-cert.pem 
{
  "__ow_meta_verb": "get",
  "__ow_meta_headers": {
    "host": "192.168.99.100:10001",
    "connection": "close",
    "user-agent": "curl/7.43.0",
    "accept": "*/*"
  },
  "__ow_meta_path": ""
}
```

@rabbah 
It would be the best if user configured the system proxy, then tests also use the same proxy settings no matter which OS user uses.

Setting up `http_proxy` and `https_proxy` environment variables are very common way.
There are many systems which recognize those environment variables.

I am not sure whether akka-http support proxy configuration.
https://github.com/akka/akka-http/issues/115

I could send the request to the container using container IP with [scalaj-http](https://github.com/scalaj/scalaj-http) which explicitly supports proxy configuration.

```
import scalaj.http._
.
.
.
it should "run sample without init" in {
    println(Http("http://172.17.0.3:5984").proxy("localhost", 3128).asString)
  }
```

I've included the CouchDB docker build into the main build. I took special care in the build script to avoid re-building the container every time, but only when something changes in `./ansible` or `./tools/db` folders. I could have been more restrictive on _which ansible scripts to watch for changes_ but I wasn't sure it's needed. If you have suggestions I'm happy to include them.

I appreciate that @mrutkows did this and applied pep8 in #1987. But I am not a fan of the 80 character lines - I find it silly (it's 2017, is it still common to print code to read it? we have high res monitors, ...) and think longer lines are actually easier to read in _some_ cases.

This project is not a python project - we have a tiny amount of python code.
Can we at least relax the line limit to 127 characters as in the linter?

I'm not going to make a bigger deal about it; I'll relunctlantly relent and move on regardless.
Closing because there's now integration testing at least in the gw repo and #1959 addresses the problem more generally.

Once we move the "code" for actions to attachments for all action kinds, we can restore the equivalent of include docs for all collections. This would give you access to all the metadata and I think is a preferred solution vs computing redundant views. It's debatable if parameters should be part of the metadata vs just annotations so the views may be necessary anyway to avoid filtering in the controller.

The second request I think could be addressed in the same way - we hide the fact that the trigger knows all its associated rules and actions. We can compute a new view or just enable include docs for triggers.  But this has related implications: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/636

All records are time stamped but as you noted the value is not exposed to clients. This would require a schema change for non-activations.
Closing as duplicate of above referenced issue.

@pjdurai an AuthKey precisely is *not* equal to a user.

One user has multiple AuthKeys, each of which have access to exactly one namespace.

Agreed on all points...  With the recent migration of code over to [openwhisk-client-python](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-client-python), Python is now just 1.5% of this repo's code.  For me 127 chars per line is a good limit.  When I write new code, I keep it to 79 characters but lots of the argparse code makes that conversion difficult.

It will be interesting to see how we rationalize https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/1987 and https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/1973 as they touch many of the same files for similar but not identical purposes.  My sense is that once it passes review, you should merge @mrutkows 's 1987 and then I can go back through 1973 manually to see if there is anything left that should still come across.

Please also review https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/1975 which concerns just one file (PythonActionContainerTests.scala) which currently contains Python 2-only code.

Let's get @mrutkows to weigh in before we close this issue.
Do not merge until AFTER merging https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/1987

@rabbah i debated putting headers in test files, but it made sense as long as there was a line of code.  The only oddball was then the "bad comment" test (i.e., "// xxxx"), but why leave just one file out...  perhaps the test will be beefed up to test a bad comment midst actual valid code.  It also helps with scanning so we do not need to do per-file exclusions when I turn on Python scanning.

wont you whave to exclude the bad comment test? You can add the license there the test should still pass. But why not exclude this entire tests/dat directory from scanning - there is nothing of value here and these headers just add annoying overhead. It's also inconsistent as I noted there are far more tests in nodejs which have no license headers. 

In other words either we should exclude all of tests/dat or apply the policy to all files consistently.
I think we can put much of that here https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/docs/cli.md and cross link. What do you think?
Closes https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/1908 perhaps?

My gut feeling is that non-SSL installations shouldn't happen in any case other than development of OpenWhisk itself. In any other deployment, the assumption should be that you've installed a proper SSL cert.

As such, it seems Vagrant specific and also, I wanted the full line there so I could copy/paste it next time I need it!
Fair although local deployments include vagrant, docker machine, or ununtu vms directly. But what I think you're pointing out is that we sort of buried all the info here anyway atm.

Yeah - there's a strong argument for refactoring the development documentation in general.

(and probably the need for some sort of "installation for production" docs)
(Rebased against latest master)
PG3#373 is green.

OK...  We are now **tantalizingly close** on this one.  Recent PRs have done much to get the codebase to be compatible with both Python 2 and Python 3.  Note: this repo is ~90% Scala and only 1.5% Python but it does use Python is a few key areas.

We created a single Docker image that contained both Python 2 and Python 3 but that proved to be [too big](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/1903#issuecomment-284717687) for daily use.  Therefore the sense is that we should transition to a world where **OpenWhisk majors in (defaults to) Python 3 and minors in Python 2**.

**We would make [dockerskeleton](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/core/actionProxy/Dockerfile) into a Python 3 container.**

For those who use the wsk syntax:
```
wsk action create myaction mysnippet.py  # use dockerskeleton-based container
wsk action create --kind python:3 myaction mysnippet.py  # use dockerskeleton-based container
wsk action create --kind python:2 myaction mysnippet.py  # use python:2.7.12-alpine-based container
```
For those who do _not_ use the CLI, OpenWhisk will just assume their code is Python 3 to be deployed on the Python 3-based dockerskeleton container.  It is not considered Pythonic to change file suffixes to .py2 and .py3 and reading file shebang lines is probably not worth the effort.

TODOs (in rough order of execution):
- [x] Finish making the code compatible with both Python 2 and Python 3
    - [x] https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/1987 (done)
    - [x] https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/2006 (done)
    - [x] https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/1973 (closed in 2006)
    - [x] https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/2007 (done)
- [ ] Move dockerskeleton from Python 2.7.12 to 2.7.13 and update pip packages and docs
    - [ ] https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/1903 (ready for review)
- [ ] Create a legacy Python docker image which matches the current dockerskeleton
    - core/python2Action is now added to 1903 
- [ ] Move dockerskeleton to Python 3.6 and update docs (go live)
- [ ] Modify wsk to accept --kind python:2 and --kind python:3
- [ ] Monitor usage and decide when to shut down legacy Python support

Also to consider: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/1940 ([venv](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/1940#issuecomment-284425619) vs. virtualenv), https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/1867, and https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/1510 

Are there any Python 3-only PyPI modules that we should consider adding to the new dockerskeleton to provide folks an incentive to switch?  I would vote for [aiohttp](http://pythonhosted.org/aiohttp/client.html#aiohttp-client) (like requests on asyncio).

got runc to work on mac just fine. I added the runc binary into the invoker container and let it use the `/run/runc` mount as before. only apparmor is not supported as docker-machine is not ubuntu-based.

enabled runc on local too, to get better test coverage with travis.

reverted my change to use both runc resume and docker unpause because they still get confused and docker unpause won't work if runc resume already unpaused the container.

in-between states (i.e. changing runc config between two invoker runs without proper `docker stop invoker0`) will be handled gracefully by the ansible playbook for invoker.

@jtyberg could you please [try changing](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/core/actionProxy/actionproxy.py#L132):

```python
process_output_lines = o.strip().split('\n')
# to
process_output_lines = str(o).strip().split('\n')
# or
process_output_lines = o.decode('utf-8').strip().split('\n')
```

@cclauss The current PR already has a line that decodes stdout _and_ stderr **IF** they are bytes (Python 3 only).  Does this suffice?

```
# stdout/stderr may be either text or bytes, depending on Python
# version.   In the latter case, decode to text.
o, e = map(lambda x: x.decode() if isinstance(x, bytes) else x, (o, e))
```

In Python 2, stdout and stderr would be text, which means `o.decode()` would not work because strings don't have a `decode` method.

```
Python 3.6.0 (v3.6.0:41df79263a11, Dec 22 2016, 17:23:13) 
[GCC 4.2.1 (Apple Inc. build 5666) (dot 3)] on darwin
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> o = u'foo'
>>> type(o)
<class 'str'>
>>> o.decode('utf-8')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
AttributeError: 'str' object has no attribute 'decode'
```
PG2 1195 green

Thanks for the explanation.  As you say, trying to deal with all string types in Python 2 and 3 is hard.
- [ ] So does your solution above work in both Python 2 and Python 3?
- [ ] Does it pass the [two tests mentioned above](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/1867#issuecomment-280817200)?
- [ ] Is this PR ready for review?
- [ ] Are there [other places](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=p.communicate%28%29&type=Code) where we could see similar bytes vs. strings issues?
